PM

City AM will no longer be produced solely by the staff team (the company is 69-strong). From now on, articles will also be generated by a raft of new 'contributors', paid according to the number of page views they generate, and – most controversially – by corporate brands and their advertising and PR teams, who will be given direct access to the content management system (CMS) of the newspaper's website.

"We are definitely turning the commercial model upside down on its head – now we will give the marketers and the advertisers access to the same content management system that all the journalists and contributors are using on a day-to-day basis," says Yardley.

PM

In it's efforts to survive, news media has just decided to screw the readers

BE

Hm.

11:06 am

Independent news? Sod that. Given 'em corporate flyers. All new meaning to "business news"

PM

It's so depressing

11:08 am

PM

Leave Taking the Lead in UK EU Referendum?
The 4 polls released this week showed a swing in favour of Leave1, rattling markets that had grown complacent about the long-standing, if slight advantage, for Remain. Remain probabilities according to betting markets also dropped markedly in the past week, from 83% to 74%.2 These moves may partly reflect numbers released by the ONS on immigration, showing net migration to the UK at 333,000 in 2015, the second highest level on record. These data were covered prominently in the media.3
Polling Trend Little Changed in Past Month, but Variations Highlight Concerns
This week, our 10-poll average still reflects a modest 3.3-point lead for Remain, at 45.2% and 41.9% for Leave – a 4.8-point decline in the Remain-Leave margin compared to the previous week when Remain had an 8.1-point lead. This is within the 3pp margin of error. Remain had a roughly 3-point lead since February up until a fortnight ago.
Too Close for Comfort
We continue to maintain a 30-40% probability of Brexit, but are increasingly concerned about the implications of continued closeness in the polls, erratic polling results4, and growing rancor within the Conservative Party for post-Referendum domestic political stability. We also note a contagion effect, at least in rhetorical terms, beyond the UK to other EU member states, as Eurosceptic populism continues to expand its brand across the Continent, with further instances of campaigns for reform and referendum likely to clog EU decision-making even if the UK votes to stay.

11:13 am
PM

A Divided Kingdom?
With 3 weeks to go till polling day, disparity in results between polling methodologies, such as online versus phone polls (covered in more detail here), account for part of the shift. Other factors beyond the horse race polling continue to support our expectation of a likely Remain result. This includes resonance of the Remain camp’s focus on the economic costs of Brexit, as well as polls showing that the Remain campaign continues to have an advantage in media exposure. For example, in the latest ORB poll, the Remain campaign is ahead when voters are asked which campaign is more “credible and trustworthy” and which campaign have you “heard from the most”.

PM

Not Just a Binary Outcome: But as we flagged last week, political and likely some market and economic risks would still result in the event of a "Close Remain" (

Here's Investec to summarise what's been said today.

11:19 am
BE

U/L FY results to March were broadly in line, with management continuing to guide to resumed growth in FY17. After the 150p special dividend in Feb, no further specials have been announced, although gearing (net debt: EBITDA at 1.1x) is below targeted levels of 1.5-2x, allowing a 5% increase in the underlying dividend to 71.5p (FY yield 2.5%). Working capital performance was strong, more than reversing FY15’s increase and leaving a strong balance sheet. No significant forecast changes expected. Buy retained

BE

Sales excluding precious metals of £3,177m compare to our £3,244m and Vara consensus of £3,201m. Underlying PBT on a continuing basis was flat yoy at £418.2m (INVe £404m, cons. £415m) leading to PTP of £351m (INVe £337m, cons £347m) and underlying EPS of 178.7p, down 1% yoy (INVe 170p, cons. 173p).
An impairment and restructuring charge of £141m was taken (£38m cash), mainly relating to the previously announced Process Technologies restructuring (£62m) and Fuel Cells review (£42m). The actions are expected to cut costs by £34mpa with an £8m benefit in FY16. Y/E Net Debt was £674.9m, leaving the balance sheet in good shape with net debt:EBITDA at 1.1x following a working cap reduction of £418.2m. ROIC of 17.3% was below the re-affirmed target of 20% and down from 18.8% YoY, but well ahead of company’s estimate of its pre-tax cost of capital of 8.1%.
Capex of £257m was c.1.8x depreciation and is expected to remain at a similar level in the year ahead as management invests to meet expected rising demand for catalysts, driven by tightening legislation. On ‘diesel-gate’, whilst some trending down of diesel sales in the EU is expected, management sees them remaining an important presence. Diesels are worth 5-7x more than a conventional gasoline catalyst. Battery Technologies revenue of £157m was up 73% yoy. Interestingly the company has licenced a nickel-rich cathode material for high density power applications, which we view positively.
Guidance remains for FY17 to be ahead of FY16 and in line with current market expectations. We expect to make only minor changes to forecasts.

BE

And Deutsche.

11:20 am
BE

H2 PBT down 6% YoY, 1% above DB and 2% above cons estimates

H2 15/16 PBT declined 6% (to GBP210m) due to weakness in Precious Metal
products and Process Technologies offsetting continuing growth in Emission
Control Technologies. This result was 2% above consensus and 1% above DB
estimates. Underlying EPS of 92p was broadly stable YoY; but was above
consensus due to lower taxes. Net Debt increased 53% vs. H1 15/16. The FY
dividend of 71.5p was up 5% despite lower earnings. Analyst meeting at 0930.

Strong growth in ECT continues
Emission Control Technologies EBIT increased 15% YoY supported by growth
in both light duty and heavy duty catalysts. LDV sales benefitted from global
car production (growth in all regions) and benefit from full implementation of
Euro6b legislation in Europe. HDD catalyst sales were supported by benefit
from growth in Western European truck production partly offsetting lower
demand for class 8 trucks in the US. Process Technologies EBIT declined 33%

YoY due to challenging market conditions in many end markets and lower oil
prices. Precious Metal Products EBIT declined 39% YoY due to weakness in
average pgm prices and absence of Gold & Silver refining. Fine Chemicals EBIT
decreased 11% YoY. Further growth was seen in New Businesses and EBIT
loss came at GBP8m. Corporate costs were lower than expected.

Outlook reiterated

Management expects earnings growth in 2016/17, in line with market
expectations and highlighted that longer term structural drivers structural
drivers are still robust. We note that cost cutting has led to
impairment/restructuring charges of £141m, of which £38m is cash. We
expect modest upgrades to consensus (low single digit %) as we expect some
at the lower end will need to upgrade.

BE

Here's the cover page. David Reynolds is the analyst.

BE

The Hitwise data set seems more relevant to MONY than to some other mobile
centric models. The long run shows some meaningful shifts in UK competitive
position, with MoneySupermarket.com no longer leading the pack. In the near
term, the expected pick up in Q216 seems more muted than we anticipated. We
trim numbers and move to Hold, PT 312p.
Why write? Given Hitwise analysis showing a weak start to 2016, muted financial
expectations, and the equity performance over the past 18 months, move to Hold, PT 312p.
Last heard, 20 April. Group revenue +9% YoY, better than consensus but off the +12% 1
March pace. Insurance -2%, Money +21%, Home Services +40%, MSE +44%, Travel -24%. 'Board remains confident of meeting its full-year expectations'.

11:34 am
BE

We look to Hitwise. Arguably the UK’s most authoritative source of online desktop and
mobile traffic analytics, Hitwise seems to be more relevant to some online models than
others. Where ‘in app’ behaviour is less relevant, as for MONY, it appears more relevant.
Hitwise, competitive shifts evident in the long run. Over the last three years, there
have been some meaningful moves in market share and MoneySupermarket.com is no
longer the market leader, according to Hitwise at any rate.
Hitwise, in the short run, not that positive for Q216. Quarter to date we have
seen a YoY visits decline of c. -13% for MoneySupermarket.com. The April dynamic showed
meaningful visit number declines across all MONY properties in stark contrast to the
competition. The May data incrementally better and a return to modest growth for the main
site, +4%, but still trailing the competition. Our sense is that MONY's return to Insurance
growth may be a little more muted than perhaps anticipated.
Cutting our numbers. It is very difficult to move confidently from the Hitwise dynamic
to a forecast income statement, nevertheless, the dynamics it shows are concerning. Today,
we cut revenue by c. 6%, c. 3% below consensus. And with the resultant deleveraging from
a reduced revenue base, we cut EBITDA more materially, by c. 13%, c. 5% below consensus.
Valuation/Risks
Consensus based MONY and peer group metrics, 14/17 Adjusted EBITDA CAGR +12%
and +26% respectively, 14/17 EPS CAGR +11% and +37%. To reflect the different growth
dynamics we use growth adjusted measures for EV/EBITDA and P/E, as well as the standard. On average, we get to a PT of 312p, cut to Hold. For CY17, 13x Adjusted EBITDA, peers 18x, and 19x Adjusted EPS, peers 25x. Key risks, competition and technology led change.

BE

Good morning,
Please see below today’s expert currency analysis from Paresh Davdra, CEO and Co-Founder of RationalFX: the UK’s first online foreign exchange service.

Do feel free to quote Paresh on the below and let us know if you would like to speak with him.

“As a result of another Brexit poll released by YouGov yesterday announced a balance between the ‘Leave’ and ‘Remain’ camps both being at 41%, the Pound lost against a host of major counterparts whilst uncertainty struck the markets again. Demand for the British Pound is therefore in an ongoing state of flux as trust in a ‘Remain’ vote falters.

Europe awaits the ECB decision later today, with a positive announcement likely to boost the Euro. In anticipation of possible interest rate variations, investors are likely to tread lightly throughout the day.”

Kind regards,
Natasha

PM

Rational FX: the UK’s first online foreign exchange service

· Rational FX has transferred over $10billion in payments

· RationalFX is set to turnover $2.6billion
· Served over 80,000 private client and business customers

· Est. 2005 by CEO & Co-Founders Paresh Davdra & Rajesh Agrawal

PM

With over $14bn worth of FX traded on a daily basis, London is the world’s largest FX trading centre and it is here that CEO and co-Founder Paresh Davdra took advantage of a gap in the money transfer market and set up the UK’s first online foreign exchange service – RationalFX.

With over a decade of foreign exchange experience combined with dynamic entrepreneurialism, Paresh Davdra has built a multi-million-pound company that makes it easy for businesses to transfer foreign currency online 24/7, and for private customers to manage payments overseas.

With a turnover of $1.9bn in 2015 and expectations to increase this to $2.6bn this year, it is clear that RationalFX is successfully making its mark on the money transfer industry. To date, the company has transacted $10bn, is growing organically with two offices in London and more in Birmingham and France, and are official sponsors of Birmingham Football Club.

11:38 am
PM

t all began in 2005 when Paresh, aged just 24, and Rajesh teamed up their foreign exchange and IT expertise, after Rajesh had complained that to remit money home at the end of every month was forcing him to part with a hefty chunk of his salary. They quit their jobs at the same brokerage firm, moved to Brighton and with one phone and one computer, RationalFX was created.

The pair had no funds whatsoever to get the business going and went knocking on banks’ doors for a loan but came back empty handed each time. Finally, they told the bank that they were interested in a £20,000 car loan and used that money to get the ball rolling.
The path to today’s success was not an easy one and in the early days, nine out of 10 people they approached turned them down. Identifying a spike in people’s interest in buying property overseas and knowing foreign investors will want to exchange currency, the pair got in touch with estate agents who would then recommend them to the house buyers and in return they paid a small commission. From there, it was word of mouth that helped snowball the company and bring in customers.

On their revenue model, RationalFX act like a wholesaler of money, exchanging a customer’s money in return for a fee. Customers choose RationalFX over the banks because they exchange money at a more competitive rate; RationalFX get a good rate of conversion from the banks because of the sheer volume of the money they exchange so customers win because they get a good rate for currency exchange and whilst RationalFX earn profits in the form of commission.

PM

We see this as the first of three re-rating catalysts to erode SKG’s 10%-15% discount to European packaging peers. Second catalyst is Smurfit Kappa’s London Capital Markets Day, on Friday, June 3 and Third catalyst: Formal FTSE 250 index inclusion as of close of business on June 17.

BE

Next Catalyst: June 3 London CMD: Smurfit Kappa hosts Capital Markets Day on Friday, June 3: (9am at London Stock Exchange), with management including Tony Smurfit CEO & Ken Bowles CFO providing detailed business overview: covering topics such as: Europe, Americas, Innovation and M&A.

Valuation Discount to Peers: Smurfit Kappa trades on consensus CY16 11.3x PE & 7.5x EV/EBITDA with 8% FCF yield, a 10%-15% discount to European packaging peers. We view Smurfit Kappa’s UK listing & FTSE index inclusion, broadening its pool of potential investors as key to unlocking this valuation discount to peers over time.

Recap on Smurfit Kappa Investment Case: Market leader in European & Latin America corrugated boxes, benefiting from: 1) European Industrial Production/Retail sales growth. 2) Market share gain (20% Pan European sales). 3) E-commerce growth, boosting corrugated packaging demand. Additionally, Smurfit Kappa allocates capital to consolidation of fragmented European & American corrugated markets.

Valuation/Risks
Retain unchanged 2016 estimates: €1,259m EBITDA & €2.06 EPS. Retain unchanged €29 PT, based on 8.2x CY16E EV/EBITDA, in line with packaging peers. SKG trades on consensus CY16 11.3x PE & 7.5x EV/EBITDA with 8% FCF yield, a 10%-15% discount to European packaging peers. Key risks: 1) Volume demand, 2) Price outlook, 3) FX.

BE

And do you want to talk kraftliner? Goodbody does.

BE

Smurfit Kappa has announced a €40/tonne price increase for white kraftliner grades from
July 1st. The company cites a continued strong demand and outlook for the grade for the
second half. The latter comment is encouraging given the continued ramp up of Stora Enso’s
Varkaus machine.
Elsewhere, Brazilian containerboard producers are implementing price increases in June
according to RISI. Klabin are attempting a 6.5% increase in kraftliner and a 10% increase in
testliner prices. West Rock is also increasing kraftliner prices immediately by 6.5%. Smurfit
Kappa’s recent entry into this market represents 1-2% of group EBITDA.
Sentiment on European pricing dynamics has turned more positive of late, which
coupled with robust demand and delayed capacity additions, gives increased
confidence in the sector outlook for 2017.

London, UK, 2 June 2016 - Premier Veterinary Group plc (LSE: PVG) announces that its wholly-owned subsidiary, Premier Vet Alliance (US) Limited ("PVA"), has signed a major agreement with Veterinary Products, Inc. ("VPI"), a significant veterinary distributor co-op, headquartered in Atlanta, Georgia, US.

The contract is to supply the Company's preventative healthcare program for pets, branded in the US as "Premier Pet Care Plan" ("PPCP"), to VPI's member hospitals numbering over 600 across 15 States, located primarily in the South East of the US.
